author: lzybkr
body:
The first time you run Add-Type, it takes on the order of 3 seconds - most of that time is spent in JIT on Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CSharp.dll and Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.dll.

```
PS C:\Program Files\PowerShell\6.0.0.9> $psversiontable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
GitCommitId                    v6.0.0-alpha.9
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
PSVersion                      6.0.0-alpha
CLRVersion
PSEdition                      Core
WSManStackVersion              3.0
BuildVersion                   3.0.0.0
```

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body:
Just to make this easy, [this](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/66f44b0517a7bc48eab1fcb49e62378409706859/build.psm1#L2035) is the list of the current assemblies being crossgen'ed.

```
        "Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.Utility.dll",
        "Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.Management.dll",
        "Microsoft.PowerShell.Security.dll",
        "Microsoft.PowerShell.CoreCLR.AssemblyLoadContext.dll",
        "Microsoft.PowerShell.CoreCLR.Eventing.dll",
        "Microsoft.PowerShell.ConsoleHost.dll",
        "Microsoft.PowerShell.PackageManagement.dll",
        "Microsoft.PowerShell.PSReadLine.dll",
        "System.Management.Automation.dll"
```

comments.author: Francisco-Gamino
comments.body: Yes, we should probably cross-gen all the assemblies that are shipped with PowerShell. I will look into it. @lzybkr, please assign the issue to me.

comments.author: Francisco-Gamino
comments.body: This issue has been fixed by #3086.

title: Consider cross-gen of additional binaries
